content.description:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “L of t, in cars per hour.” There are 5 columns of data in the table. The data are as follows. Column 1. t is 2. L of t is 15. Column 2. t is 5. L of t is 40. Column 3. t is 9. L of t is 24. Column 4. t is 11. L of t is 68. Column 5. t is 12. L of t is 18." overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="false" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"> <mtr> <mtd> <mtable> <mtr> <mtd> <mi>t</mi> </mtd> </mtr> <mtr> <mtd> <mtext>(hours)</mtext> </mtd> </mtr> </mtable> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>2</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>5</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>9</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>11</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>12</mn> </mtd> </mtr> <mtr> <mtd> <mtable> <mtr> <mtd> <mi>L</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mtd> </mtr> <mtr> <mtd> <mtext>(cars per hour)</mtext> </mtd> </mtr> </mtable> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>15</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>40</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>24</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>68</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>18</mn> </mtd> </mtr> </mtable> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>

The rate at which cars enter a parking lot is modeled by <math alttext="E of t equals, 30 plus, 5 times, open parenthesis, t minus 2, close parenthesis, times open parenthesis, t minus 5, close parenthesis, times e raised to the negative 0.2 t power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. The rate at which cars leave the parking lot is modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="L of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. Both <math alttext="E of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in cars per hour, and time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours after <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> A.M. (<math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>). Both functions are defined for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: (a) What is the rate of change of <math alttext="E of t" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>E</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> at time <math alttext="t equals 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?  Indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text: (a) What is the rate of change of <math alttext="E of t" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>E</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> at time <math alttext="t equals 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?  Indicate units of measure.

(b) How many cars enter the parking lot from time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to time <math alttext="t equals 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?  Give your answer to the nearest whole number.

(c) Use a trapezoidal sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from, 2 to 12, of, L of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="the integral from, 2 to 12, of, L of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> in the context of this problem.

(d) For <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, less than 6" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo><</mo> <mn>6</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dollars are collected from each car entering the parking lot. For <math alttext="6 is less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dollars are collected from each car entering the parking lot. How many dollars are collected from the cars entering the parking lot from time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to time <math alttext="t equals 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?  Give your answer to the nearest whole dollar.

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
